question.title: How to detect the end of the loop (for each)?

node.contents: This is often a case where a standard for loop is used instead of a foreach.

astNode.text: This is often a case where a standard for loop is used instead of a foreach.

node.contents: @Mitch Wheat: I'm aware of that, but if there's just a simple method to know at the end. It would be a great help. Like using `resultSet.next();` there is a `resultSet.isLast()`. I'm looking for that kind of method, if it is also available in `foreach`.

astNode.text: @Mitch Wheat: I'm aware of that, but if there's just a simple method to know at the end. It would be a great help. Like using `resultSet.next();` there is a `resultSet.isLast()`. I'm looking for that kind of method, if it is also available in `foreach`.

node.contents: That sort of method is usually available on the iterator (something like `hasNext`). The whole point of the for each loop is to abstract away the iterator; unfortunately, this also means you have slightly reduced functionality.

astNode.text: That sort of method is usually available on the iterator (something like `hasNext`). The whole point of the for each loop is to abstract away the iterator; unfortunately, this also means you have slightly reduced functionality.

node.contents: `str.length` is not the proper length that you are looking for. It should be `arrayString.length`.

astNode.text: `str.length` is not the proper length that you are looking for. It should be `arrayString.length`.

node.contents: @pickypg: I know it just a sample code. My actual code is far complicated than that.

astNode.text: @pickypg: I know it just a sample code. My actual code is far complicated than that.

node.contents: Using for(int i = 0; i < str.length; i++) I can easily detect if the loop is at the end.

astNode.text: Using for(int i = 0; i < str.length; i++) I can easily detect if the loop is at the end.

node.contents: But I how can I know if I'm using for or for each.

astNode.text: But I how can I know if I'm using for or for each.

elements.contents: for(String str : arrayString){ if(End of for) //Do something if the end of the loop }

fragments.text: ){ if(End of for) //Do something if the end of the loop }

units.rawText: for(String str : arrayString){ if(End of for) //Do something if the end of the loop }

node.contents: The reason I use for(:) instead of for(;;) is that str is actually a large Object which I need to use that property for another loop inside that loop. And I don't like using much object.get(index).getProperty It just also for convenience to me in doing the coding. That's why I want to know if the for(:) loop is at the last index.

astNode.text: The reason I use for(:) instead of for(;;) is that str is actually a large Object which I need to use that property for another loop inside that loop. And I don't like using much object.get(index).getProperty It just also for convenience to me in doing the coding. That's why I want to know if the for(:) loop is at the last index.

node.contents: UPDATE

astNode.text: UPDATE

node.contents: My interim solution is to assign a int variable that will hold the number of iteration. Then check if the variable is equal to the length of the str.length.

astNode.text: My interim solution is to assign a int variable that will hold the number of iteration. Then check if the variable is equal to the length of the str.length.

node.contents: @Jigar Fair enough, but it wasn't when I posted it. @ace As noted by Tikhon, you can use an `Iterator` for your collection, but I assumed that was not valid since you showed an array up top.

astNode.text: @Jigar Fair enough, but it wasn't when I posted it. @ace As noted by Tikhon, you can use an `Iterator` for your collection, but I assumed that was not valid since you showed an array up top.

node.contents: Two easy ways, which are somewhat amusing given your reasoning for using the foreach loop.

astNode.text: Two easy ways, which are somewhat amusing given your reasoning for using the foreach loop.

elements.contents: int i = 1; for (String str : arrayString) { if (i++ == arrayString.length) { // end } }

node.contents: Or

astNode.text: Or

elements.contents: for (int i = 0; i < arrayString.length; ++i) { String str = arrayString[i]; if (i + 1 == arrayString.length) { // end } }

node.contents: Effectively the same thing. Just note the difference between the use of i within the if between the two loops and the starting value of i.

astNode.text: Effectively the same thing. Just note the difference between the use of i within the if between the two loops and the starting value of i.

node.contents: @ace: Using a straight for loop would be more efficient, but possibly less elegant. But you should generally be more concerned with writing maintainable code and then *measure* the performance, rather than guessing where your bottlenecks are.

astNode.text: @ace: Using a straight for loop would be more efficient, but possibly less elegant. But you should generally be more concerned with writing maintainable code and then *measure* the performance, rather than guessing where your bottlenecks are.

node.contents: I'am more concerned with maintainable code that's why I'm looking for another way to check that last index of the loop. But I'm not still good at it, anyway I'll keep your solution then if I have more time I'm going to use it. Thanks

node.contents: One option would be to write your own iterator implementation which exposed, at each point, properties of first, last, index and value.

astNode.text: One option would be to write your own iterator implementation which exposed, at each point, properties of first, last, index and value.

node.contents: I've done the same thing for .NET, and it was far from tricky. In Java it would be even easier, as you could use the hasNext() method of the original iterator to determine whether or not it's the last element. The code would look something like this (completely untested):

astNode.text: I've done the same thing for .NET, and it was far from tricky. In Java it would be even easier, as you could use the hasNext() method of the original iterator to determine whether or not it's the last element. The code would look something like this (completely untested):

elements.contents: public SmartIterable<T> implements Iterable<SmartIterator<T>.Entry> { private final Iterable<T> iterable; public SmartIterable(Iterable<T> iterable) { this.iterable = iterable; } public Iterator<T> iterator() { return new SmartIterator<T>(iterable.iterator()); } } public SmartIterator<T> implements Iterator<SmartIterator<T>.Entry> { private final Iterator<T> iterator; private int index = -1; SmartIterator(Iterator<T> iterator) { this.iterator = iterator; } public void remove() { // Could potentially just delegate throw new UnsupportedOperationException(); } public boolean hasNext() { return iterator.hasNext(); } public Entry next() { T nextValue = iterator.next(); index++; return new Entry(nextValue, index); } public class Entry { private final int index; private final T value; private Entry(int index, T value) { this.index = index; this.value = value; } public T getValue() { return value; } public int getIndex() { return index; } public boolean isFirst() { return index == 0; } public boolean isLast() { // Call into containing instance return !hasNext(); } } }

comments.text: // Could potentially just delegate throw new UnsupportedOperationException(); } public boolean hasNext() { return iterator.hasNext(); } public Entry next() { T nextValue = iterator.next(); index++; return new Entry(nextValue, index); } public class Entry { private final int index; private final T value; private Entry(int index, T value) { this.index = index; this.value = value; } public T getValue() { return value; } public int getIndex() { return index; } public boolean isFirst() { return index == 0; } public boolean isLast() { // Call into containing instance return !hasNext(); } } }
